examples.title: Algebraic vs Transcendental
examples.statement: Define algebraic and transcendental numbers and give examples.

steps.title: Definition
steps.content:
A number $\alpha$ is algebraic if it satisfies some polynomial equation with integer coefficients: $a_nx^n + \cdots + a_0 = 0$.
Otherwise, it is transcendental.

exercises.statement: Show that $\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{3}$ is algebraic by finding its minimal polynomial.

examples.title: Algebraic Integers
examples.statement: Define algebraic integers and prove that the sum of algebraic integers is an algebraic integer.

steps.title: Definition
steps.content: An algebraic integer is a root of a monic polynomial with integer coefficients.

steps.title: Closure under addition
steps.content:
If $\alpha$ satisfies $x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_0 = 0$
and $\beta$ satisfies $x^m + b_{m-1}x^{m-1} + \cdots + b_0 = 0$,
then $\alpha + \beta$ satisfies a monic polynomial of degree $nm$.

exercises.statement: Show that $\frac{1 + \sqrt{5}}{2}$ (the golden ratio $\phi$) is an algebraic integer.

solution.conclusion: $\phi$ satisfies $x^2 - x - 1 = 0$, a monic polynomial, so it's an algebraic integer.
